title: Well...
content:
He's designing the face in it's extreme/stretched position, so that when it folds into a "normal" position, it looks "relaxed." Go look in a mirror at the corners of your eyes when you're relaxed and idle--see how wrinkled and bunched up they look? Now open your eyes really really wide, as wide as you can, and look at them--see how they look like the mesh DSL is working on?

Similarly, as he models the arms, he'll probably model them outstretched to either side, as if Billy were preparing to hug a refridgerator-sized object... this is for the same reason. Modelling something in its most extended/stretched position makes the default posture appear relaxed--which is important for helping animation appear fluid and natural.

At least, that's my impression...

[quote]Quote:[hr]Similarly, as he models the arms, he'll probably model them outstretched to either side, as if Billy were preparing to hug a refridgerator-sized object... this is for the same reason. Modelling something in its most extended/stretched position makes the default posture appear relaxed--which is important for helping animation appear fluid and natural.[hr][/quote]

well modeling a character in the classic T pose has nothing to do with animating actually, the T pose is only useful when setting up the skeleton structure for the model.

if you want the best model pose for animating purposes you should model everything in a 45 degree angle. then the mesh will not be heavily deformed when rotating a joint to the extremes. also it keeps the texture from stretching to much with the mesh [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]


anyway enough technical gibberish.
thanks for the point out with the helmet XkyRauh2001!
altough i was going to remake the hemlet from scratch i never considered the helmet to be sloping straight down at the forehead, something that could make the helmet appear more tall. i will keep that in mind [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]
